column2: In real life elections: * Organizing bribing campaigns is illegal * Ballots are not just secret by default, but unprovable even if the voter *wants* to prove who they voted for Both are essential; see 19th century before this was the case.

But there are some non-technical BCH people making noise about 0-conf right now, so it has become difficult to have a sane conversation.

The argument is that, because there's no RBF, 0-conf works on BCH, with some (uncharacterized) degree of risk, for small transactions where the merchant shoulders that risk. There are plans to improve the current state of 0-conf.

I suspect folks are getting upset by this metaphor because it's extremely difficult for people to change their social class IRL. In crypto it's relatively easy - the onus is on each user to choose their security model. I myself am constantly promoting education around this point.
There are no official classes; this is a metaphor for the power wielded by users relative to the security model that they choose.

You can say "it's not enough," or "it's not improving fast enough," or any other number of perfectly reasonable things. What you cannot say is: "It's not happening." It is.
"People of color are living longer than they did 30 years ago and the gap between races in life expectancy" isn't an opinion, Kelly. It's not something you "argue."
The unfounded confidence of newbies at things gets an empirical look, and it turns out: newbies overestimate themselves.https://twitter.com/shallenberg/status/980231833009860608 …
You can argue with it all day. "Better" doesn't mean "perfect." It means "continually improving." You seem invested in a narrative of increasing misery. *Everyone* is living longer.
Worthy targets, actually.
https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/to-your-health/wp/2017/05/02/cdc-life-expectancy-up-for-blacks-and-the-racial-gap-is-closing/?utm_term=.798b41f8385b …

I believe in market solutions. Ingraham (whom I also loathe) doesn't have a right to have someone advertise on her show. What burns me is the "just fire this guy" stuff that comes with it, which is a different matter. Maybe shading a difference, but an important one to me.

Also, I'm all for boycotting the advertisers. Ben and I disagree there. But having been at the other ends of "fire this guy" campaigns, I share his distaste for the way activists - of BOTH sides - do things now.

No offense taken! I'll also admit I wasn't smart enough to fully comprehend Voegelin, maybe I'll still not. I just think ignorant paranoia and Gnosticism are two different animals. (Same genus, maybe.)

They weren't alive during Reagan, and they are coming of age at a time of unprecedented wealth, technological advancement, the longest life spans in human history, and a culture that thinks they're awesome. They'll be fine.

I understand, and yes, I studied Gnosticism in grad school. (I went to Georgetown, how could I not?) Voegelin's objection to empirical absolutism, imo, has nothing to do with this. These are not people who think they're unraveling the true nature of reality. They're paranoids.

Yeah, except there was some walking around and eating food and some words with a guy named Thomas before the Ascension and being seated and all. Like, there were weeks of doing stuff.
cc @ bterris

Which is not to say that the Gnostics were right, but that they came from a hyper-scholasticism that believed it could find divine revelation. This is more pedestrian: "Other humans are hiding knowledge from us, and only I'm smart enough to know it." So, very different.

It's a good question. I'd say no, because the Gnostics were people who were convinced that learning and deep study could reveal truths. This is different: this is a paranoid's version of self-empowerment. It begins from a narcissistic assumption that everyone is stupid but you.
I don't disagree, I'm only saying: there's a lot of accusations I'll get through before I even *get* to that.

I don't know. Both of my parents were veterans and I believe the honor guard said something like "on behalf of a grateful nation" or something like that when I received their flags at the grave. But not "spiritual heritage."
